Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2009 04:11AM DrawnToScale wrote: I had my genetic test done at Johns Hopkins.  They tested for the 3 defects common in Ashkenazi Jews.  My results show "deleterious mutation" for BRCA2. I would think that parents (or those looking to become parents) would do what they can to provide the best for their child.  Isn't a 50-80% likelihood of early onset cancer worth avoiding?   Has the survival rate for breast or ovarian cancer changed much over the last 20-30 years?  I'm counting on (and so is my genetics councelor) similar outcomes 20-30 years from now.  As for legitimate reasons to abort - many people abort simply because they are not ready for a child.  Isn't this an even better reason? My sister (who is BRCA1+ and was diagnosed with BC at age 39 and had double mastectomy & ovaries out) tells me that if I have a child the "normal" way, that would be the ultimate in selfishness.  What do you think of her opinon?  Joel
Posts.Title: BRCA 2+..still want to have children.. what can I do? MKMS22

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2009 06:09PM - edited Sep 15, 2009 06:11PM by DrawnToScale I see there are no men writing here, but I'll give my perspective.   Although my sister is BRCA1+, and she, my aunt and grandmother all were diagnosed with breast cancer in their 30s - I had no plan to be tested until I got married a few months ago.  I was surprised to find that I am BRCA2+ (unlike my sister's BRCA1).   After watching my sister go through double mastectomy, reconstruction, and ovaries out - I feel I really don't want to pass this mutation to my children.   With some consultation with a genetic counselor - we briefly considered PGD IVF, but its really expensive - and my wife doesn't want to do it.  Our counselor suggested getting a test on the fetus at 11 weeks and consider abortion if its BRCA+ and female or other nasty problems.  My wife would abort in the case of downs or other immediate onset conditions - but wouldn't abort for BRCA+.   She would prefer to "throw the dice" and hope for the best, or to go sperm donor.  I'm uncomfortable with these options at the moment.  I'm hoping that through more discussion and more counseling - we will come to a solution that will feel reasonable for both of us.   Anyone out there who has had a child - knowing beforehand their BRCA+ condition?   I'm thinking that there would be too much guilt later on if a girl inherited my gene that I didn't HAVE to pass on.  Any thoughts on that?  Thanks, Joel

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2009 11:41PM DrawnToScale wrote: Thank you Mutd.  You sound like a very informed and thoughtful person.  As my wife and I work our way through this decision process, ideas and information like what you provided will certainly help us.  The 2 people I know who are BRCA1+ who had not yet been diagnosed with BC both did the same thing - preventative removal of ovaries & breasts.   I think I would have done the same.  However - it sounds like in your last post that careful monitoring followed by surgery as a treatment may be substitute for prophalactic surgery.   Now - I'm not woman, so I can't quite put myself in those shoes - but wouldn't one want to reduce one's risk of cancer as much as possible?  Thank you.
